newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak far-right invites National Front's Le Pen.
newsitem.headline: Slovak far-right invites National Front's Le Pen.

text.p: The far-right Slovak National Party said on Tuesday it has invited Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of its French counterpart the National Front, to visit Bratislava this spring.

"We would like to discuss creation of an association, or community, of nationally-oriented parties of Europe," Jan Slota, chairman of the SNS, which is a partner in Slovakia's ruling coalition, told the independent radio Twist.
Slovak opposition politicians said they would hold protest marches if Le Pen came to Bratislava.

Slota attended a National Front congress in Strasbourg last weekend at which Le Pen urged European far-rightists to join forces while an estimated 40,000 anti-Front demonstrators marched in protest of his racial policies.
"I saw blacks making a huge noise banging drums on the main square (of Strasbourg). I saw broken shop-windows... drunk blacks and Arabs and a couple of anti-socials," he told the radio.
"Those Frenchmen who were at the congress were democrats while those in the looted stores... were far away from democracy."
Slota said Le Pen was expected to visit in late April or early May. "A date has not yet been set but the visit itself certainly was... We will try to arrange meetings at the (top) level," he said.
The opposition Social-Democratic Party issued a statement saying "Slota is putting Slovaks into one basket with Le Pen... and other extremist politicians, who are a disgrace to their countries."

Peter Zajac, vice chairman of the Democratic Party, told Reuters: "It is all the worse that the SNS is a member of the ruling coalition and in a democratic Europe this can create the impression that Le Pen's politics are acceptable to the Slovak government."
